At that time, the troops of the Asura king won the victory.
The heavenly multitudes of the Trayastriá¹ƒÅ›a Heaven retreated in defeat, fleeing in terror.
At that time, Åšakra, Lord of the Devas,

I am now the king of the asuras, leading the troops to wage war.
The troops of the Heaven of the Thirty-three have retreated in fear, scattering and running in all directions.
What expedient means can save me from this difficulty?

Svaha
The Buddha said to the Lord of the Heaven of the Thirty-three:
This invincible banner adornment dhÄraá¹‡Ä«
Always protects internally and externally.
You should uphold this dhÄraá¹‡Ä«,
Wrap it in multi-colored silk, and tie it to the top of your banner.
When you go to a place
Where you are fighting, arguing, or killing with others,
Or competing in words with enemies, you will be victorious in all places.
You should write this dhÄraá¹‡Ä«
And wrap it in a pouch to protect you.
I will also do this for the future world.
The benevolent kings of the world will all protect him everywhere.
The Tathagata Ajitasena
will manifest the form of a celestial maiden in front of him.
Granting him fearlessness, he will be protected and victorious.
He will cause the armies of his enemies to be scattered and defeated.
If the benevolent king is able to write, disseminate, uphold,
recite and chant this dharani,
he will always obtain pure and auspicious things.
No external enemies will be able to defeat him.
After the Buddha had spoken this sutra,
Indra, the lord of the gods, and the various celestial beings,
having heard what the Buddha had said, all greatly rejoiced.
They accepted it in faith and practiced it, bowed and withdrew.
The Sutra of the Invincible Banner Adornment Dharani
